article_title: Rates going up for Texans in health marketplace
article_text:
Rates going up for Texans in health marketplace Houstonians to pay an average of nearly 5 percent more next year

Photo: Manuel Balce Ceneta, STF Health and Human Services Secretary Sylvia Burwell will be in town... Texans buying coverage through the federally mandated health insurance marketplace will face an average 5.1 percent rate increase for benchmark plans in 2016, a new Health and Human Services analysis released Monday afternoon showed.

To continue reading this story, you will need to be a digital subscriber to HoustonChronicle.com. Houston Chronicle subscribers have FREE access to all premium digital products.

By logging in, you agree to the Terms and Conditions and Privacy Policy.

article_metadata.description: Texans buying coverage through the federally mandated health insurance marketplace will face an average 5.1 percent rate increase for benchmark plans in 2016, a new Health and Human Services analysis released Monday afternoon showed.  In June, HHS made public on the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services website any insurer asking for a rate increase of more than 10 percent.  In Texas, Scott & White Health Plan asked for a 32.4 percent average increase in its individual silver plan and a 31 percent increase in its bronze plan; Humana proposed raising one of its individual plans by an average of 29.73 percent; and Blue Cross Blue Shield asked for a 19.97 percent increase for its Blue Advantage HMO individual plan.  Federal officials have said the sting of any rate increase typically is lessened because the vast majority of enrollees receive subsidies to make their premiums more affordable.  [...] there is speculation from those watching the exchange that customers may have to switch plans for 2016 to realize those low premiums, especially as insurers make changes to their offerings and provider networks narrow.
article_metadata.author.name: By Jenny Deam

og.description: Texans buying coverage through the federally mandated health insurance marketplace will face an average 5.1 percent rate increase for benchmark plans in 2016, a new Health and Human Services analysis released Monday afternoon showed.  In June, HHS made public on the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services website any insurer asking for a rate increase of more than 10 percent.  In Texas, Scott & White Health Plan asked for a 32.4 percent average increase in its individual silver plan and a 31 percent increase in its bronze plan; Humana proposed raising one of its individual plans by an average of 29.73 percent; and Blue Cross Blue Shield asked for a 19.97 percent increase for its Blue Advantage HMO individual plan.  Federal officials have said the sting of any rate increase typically is lessened because the vast majority of enrollees receive subsidies to make their premiums more affordable.  [...] there is speculation from those watching the exchange that customers may have to switch plans for 2016 to realize those low premiums, especially as insurers make changes to their offerings and provider networks narrow.
